texts.shortText:
Forms tall, dark-green, tree-like growths of soft spongy branches emerging from a single holdfast. The repeatedly branching fronds are fairly thick and obviously flattened at the branches (and sometimes the tips).

Internally the branches are made up of large interwoven tubes that are each single multinucleated cells. On the surface these emerge as distinct swellings (utricles) and the shapes of these needs to be examined microscopically to distinguish between many of the species. In this species the utricles are unusually large (about 1 mm) with rounded apices and may sometimes bear hairs (variable).
Total height typically about 300 mm with flattened branches reaching at least 40 mm wide.

Global: Namibia, South Africa, Mozambique, Kenya, Oman, Vietnam, Australia and New Zealand

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.

Intertidal pools and on shallow sublittoral reefs across the region. Like other species in this genus fed on by sap-sucking sea slugs, mostly of the genus Elysia, which penetrate the large calls and suck up the contents, including the chloroplasts, which continue to photosynthesize within the slug’s body, making it essentially ‘solar-powered’.

Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.

There are several similar, tree-like species in this genus and the utricles need to be examined under the microscope for accurate identification. This species has unusually large, rounded utricles. Other similar species in the region include C fragile (small apical spines on utricles)) and C. extricatum (hairs on tips of utricles).
